awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Paramagnetic metal-ion labeling methods to measure mechanism of transcriptional activation in  P. aeruginosa
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop experimental and simulation methodology to elucidate the sensing and transcription mechanism of protein CueR from P. aeruginosa.  CueR binds to cellular Copper ions with very high affinity that leads to the binding of this protein to a specific site on DNA. This, in turn, activates the transcription of proteins that take the metal ion out of the cell to prevent toxicity and cell death. The results of this study will provide atomistic details of protein and DNA structure and conformational dynamics that enable the regulation of copper levels inside the cells of bacteria.  The project will also firm up an international collaboration and allow the continuation of a multi-pronged effort to enhance opportunities for under-represented groups to participate in science.  These include outreach to high-school students, providing access of Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (EPR) instrumentation to two primarily undergraduate institutions, the creation of new labs for undergraduate curriculum, and the graduate and undergraduate research training of a diverse group of students.

The project will generate a holistic understanding of the sensing and transcription mechanism of the copper metal sensor in bacteria. The project will develop methodology to site specifically label and model DNA with Cu2+-ions and develop techniques to measure site-specific dynamics using a novel Cu2+ label for proteins. In addition, point to point distances, elastic network modeling and molecular dynamics will be used to obtain structural information on the P. aeruginosa CueR protein and DNA in different functional states during the transcriptional cycle. Another centrally innovative aspect of this project is that the work will provide the wider biophysical community with new spin labeling and simulation approaches to measure structural constraints and flexibility in both DNA as well as proteins. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics and Genetic Mechanism Clusters of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With support from the NSF BSF grant we have made strides in the development of site-directed Cu(II) spin labeling and applied this methodology to shed light on transcriptional activation in the CueR system. Using an integrated computational and experimental approach we have streamlined data acquisition schemes so that high quality data on can be acquired on as little as 25 nM – 75 mM concentrations of protein. The reduction in the amount n needed for experiments opens up the methodology to challenging proteins that are either hard to express or prone to aggregation at higher concentrations. We have developed force fields for the labels to couple the experimental measurement of structural  constraints with molecular dynamics. Such coupling has provided a new pathway for resolving function associated structural changes in proteins. In addition, we have made strides in understanding the mechanism of transcriptional activation and termination in metalloregulator CueR. Our work on the CueR protein has shown that: (a) There are multiple Cu(I) binding sites in the protein; (b) the primary mechanism for the activation of transcriptional regulation by this protein occurs through an allosteric mechanism. More precisely, we show that Cu(I) binding at the metal binding domain leads to dramatic changes in the dynamical fluctuation of the DNA binding domain, which is ca. 3 nm distant from the metal binding domain! Such changes in dynamics enable efficient binding to the DNA; (c) finally, using distance measurements on the DNA, we show that the metal-free protein-DNA complex can have the same DNA kink as the metal-bound protein-DNA complex. This result provides a direct understanding of the genesis of both transcriptional activation and repression. Twenty-four publications have resulted from the work.

The grant has contributed to a multi-pronged effort to enhance opportunities for under-represented groups to participate in science. These include outreach to high-school students, providing access of ESR instrumentation to one primarily undergraduate institution, and the graduate and undergraduate research training of a diverse group of students. Eight undergraduate researchers and ten graduate students working on this project were trained at the interdisciplinary interface between chemistry and biophysics. Of these eighteen trainees, ten were women and one is a member of an under-represented group. The PI has expanded access to pulsed ESR instrumentation to undergraduates at a 4-year college in Pennsylvania. The PI hosted high-school and middle school students during workshops and  orient them with the NSF supported research. Research ideas and themes developed in the project were used to modernize an undergraduate Physical Chemistry course.
